title: Apple Vision Pro
content:
{{Short description|Upcoming mixed reality headset by Apple Inc.}} {{Redirect|Vision Pro|the non-linear editing system|D/Vision Pro}} {{Use American English|date=June 2023}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}} {{Infobox computing device | logo = Apple_Vision_Pro.svg | image = Apple Vision Pro (non-free image).png | caption = Apple Vision Pro headset and its battery pack | developer = [[Apple Inc.]] | manufacturer = [[Luxshare]] | type = Standalone [[mixed reality]] headset | price = {{USD|3499}} | display = '''Internal:''' ~23 [[Pixel#Megapixel|MP]] total (equivalent to [[Computer display standard|WUHD]] for each eye) dual micro-[[OLED]] (RGBB π [[subpixel geometry]]) up to 96 Hz [[refresh rate]]{{cite web |last1=Brown |first1=Rory |title=Apple Vision Pro: Full Specification – VRcompare |url=https://vr-compare.com/headset/applevisionpro |website=VRcompare |access-date=June 7, 2023 |language=en |archive-date=June 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230607104047/https://vr-compare.com/headset/applevisionpro |url-status=live }}
'''External:''' "EyeSight" [[Curved screen|curved]] OLED{{Cite web |title=Apple's EyeSight Feature on Vision Pro Is Creepier Than It Needs to Be |url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/apples-eyesight-feature-on-vision-pro-is-creepier-than-it-needs-to-be/ |access-date=2023-08-08 |website=[[CNET]] |language=en}} | graphics = {{Ubl | [[Apple M2]] (10 cores) @ 3.5 GHz, up to 3.578 TFLOPS{{citation|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/apple-m2-gpu-analysis|title=Don't Believe the Hype: Apple's M2 GPU is No Game Changer|date=June 7, 2022 }} }} | [[Field of view|FoV]] = | sound = [[Surround sound]] speakers, 6 microphones {{cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro/|title=Introducing Apple Vision Pro |access-date=December 29, 2023}} | input = [[Six degrees of freedom|6DoF]] inside-out tracking, [[photogrammetry]], and [[gesture recognition]] through 12 built-in cameras and [[lidar]] | processor = [[Apple M2]] and [[Apple R1|R1]] | weight = | os = visionOS ([[iOS]]-based) | website = {{URL|https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro/|apple.com/apple-vision-pro}} | releasedate = Early 2024 in the [[United States]] }} '''Apple Vision Pro''' is an upcoming [[mixed-reality]] headset developed by [[Apple Inc.|Apple Inc]]. It was announced on June 5, 2023, at Apple's [[Worldwide Developers Conference]], with availability scheduled for early 2024 in the [[United States]] and later that year internationally. It is Apple's first product in another major category since the [[Apple Watch]] in 2015.{{cite web |last=Wong |first=Aloysius |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple announces new VR headset Vision Pro, to launch next year |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/apple-vr-headset-announcement-1.6865872 |access-date=7 June 2023 |website=[[CBC News]]}} Apple advertises the Vision Pro as a "[[Spatial computing|spatial computer]]", where digital media is integrated with the real world and physical inputs, such as motion gestures, [[eye tracking]], and [[Speech recognition|voice input]], can be used to interact with the system. Primarily intended as a standalone device booting visionOS, a derivative of [[iOS]] designed to run its own [[extended reality]] apps, it can also be wirelessly connected to a [[Mac (computer)|Mac]].{{Cite web |title=Apple Vision Pro VR Headset Release Date Confirmed - TechShaky |url=https://techshaky.com/apple-vision-pro-vr-headset-release-date-confirmed/ |access-date=2023-10-30 |language=en-US}} ==History== === Development === In May 2015, Apple acquired the German [[augmented reality]] (AR) company [[Metaio]], originally [[Corporate spin-off|spun off]] from [[Volkswagen]].{{Cite web |last=Wakabayashi |first=Daisuke |date=May 28, 2015 |title=Apple Buys German Augmented-Reality Firm Metaio |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-41998 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |archive-date=May 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230517101845/https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-41998 |url-status=live }} rumored to be originally motivated by [[Apple electric car project|Project Titan]].{{Cite web |last=Heaney |first=David |date=May 20, 2022 |title=Report Details The Troubled Development Delaying Apple's AR/VR Headset |url=https://www.uploadvr.com/the-information-apple-headset-troubled-report/ |access-date=June 26, 2023 |website=[[UploadVR]] |archive-date=June 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230626111733/https://www.uploadvr.com/the-information-apple-headset-troubled-report/ |url-status=live }} That year, Apple hired Mike Rockwell from [[Dolby Laboratories]]. Rockwell formed a team that included Metaio {{Nowrap|co-founder}} Peter Meier and [[Apple Watch]] manager Fletcher Rothkopf. The team, called the Technology Development Group, developed an AR demo in 2016 but faced opposition from then-chief design officer [[Jony Ive]] and his team. Augmented reality and [[virtual reality]] (VR) expert and former [[NASA]] specialist Jeff Norris was hired in April 2017.{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=April 24, 2017 |title=Apple Hires NASA AR Guru to Help Run Its Own Efforts |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-24/apple-hires-nasa-ar-guru-to-help-run-its-own-efforts |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920225552/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-24/apple-hires-nasa-ar-guru-to-help-run-its-own-efforts |archive-date=September 20, 2022 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}}{{cite web |last1=Gurman |first1=Mark |title=Apple Renames Mixed-Reality Software 'xrOS' in Sign Headset Is Approaching |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-01/apple-mixed-reality-headset-rivaling-meta-set-to-run-xros-operating-system |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |access-date=May 27, 2023 |language=en |date=December 1, 2022 |archive-date=May 13, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230513154634/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-01/apple-mixed-reality-headset-rivaling-meta-set-to-run-xros-operating-system |url-status=live }} Rockwell's team helped deliver [[ARKit]] in 2017 with [[iOS 11]]. Rockwell's team sought to create a headset and worked with Ive's team; the decision to reveal the wearer's eyes through a front-facing eye display went over well with the industrial design team.{{Cite web |last=Ma |first=Wayne |date=May 20, 2022 |title=Behind the Apple Design Decisions That Bogged Down Its Mixed-Reality Headset |url=https://www.theinformation.com/articles/behind-the-apple-design-decisions-that-bogged-down-its-mixed-reality-headset |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Information (website)|The Information]] |archive-date=May 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230509141145/https://www.theinformation.com/articles/behind-the-apple-design-decisions-that-bogged-down-its-mixed-reality-headset |url-status=live }} The headset's development experienced a period of uncertainty with the departure of Ive in 2019. His successor, Evans Hankey, left the company in 2023.{{Cite web |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian |date=March 26, 2023 |title=At Apple, Rare Dissent Over a New Product: Interactive Goggles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The New York Times]] |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605022359/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |url-status=live }} Senior engineering manager Geoff Stahl, who reports to Rockwell, led the development of its visionOS [[operating system]],{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Live: Apple Headset, iOS 17 and Other WWDC 2023 Updates |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/live-blog/2023-06-05/apple-worldwide-developers-conference |access-date=6 June 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |language=en}} after previously working on games and graphics technology at Apple.{{cite web |last1=Evans |first1=Jonny |title=Will Apple play nice with others to make Siri smarter? |url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/3274554/will-apple-play-nice-with-others-to-make-siri-smarter.html |website=Computerworld |access-date=May 28, 2023 |language=en |date=May 21, 2018 |archive-date=May 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230528090051/https://www.computerworld.com/article/3274554/will-apple-play-nice-with-others-to-make-siri-smarter.html |url-status=live }} Apple's extended reality headset is meant as a bridge to future lightweight AR glasses, which are not yet technically feasible.{{cite news |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian X. |title=At Apple, Rare Dissent Over a New Product: Interactive Goggles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |access-date=12 June 2023 |work=The New York Times |date=26 March 2023}}{{Cite web |last=Lawler |first=Richard |date=January 18, 2023 |title=Apple reportedly shelved its plans to release AR glasses anytime soon |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/17/23560097/apple-ar-vr-glasses-headset-rumor-mixed-reality |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605061356/https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/17/23560097/apple-ar-vr-glasses-headset-rumor-mixed-reality |url-status=live }} In November 2017, Apple acquired Canadian XR company Vrvana for $30 million. The Vrvana Totem was able to overlay fully opaque, true-color animations on top of the real world rather than the ghost-like projections of other AR headsets, which cannot display the color black. It was able to do this while avoiding the often noticeable lag between the cameras capturing the outside world while simultaneously maintaining a 120-degree field of view at 90 Hz. The Totem also used IR illuminators and infrared cameras to perform spatial and hand tracking. {{Cite web |author1=Kevin Carbotte |date=2016-10-21 |title=Vrvana Totem Mixed Reality HMD Prototype: Beyond Expectations |url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/vrvana-totem-mixed-reality-prototype,32896.html |access-date=2023-06-12 |website=Tom's Hardware |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Lunden |first=Lucas Matney and Ingrid |date=2017-11-21 |title=Apple acquired augmented reality headset startup Vrvana for $30M |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/21/apple-acquires-mixed-reality-headset-startup-vrvana-for-30m/ |access-date=2023-06-12 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} According to leaker Wayne Ma, Apple was originally going to allow macOS software to be dragged from the display to the user's environment, but was scrapped early on due to the limitations of being based on iOS, and noted that the hand-tracking system was not precise enough to game. Workers also discussed collaborations with brands such as Nike for working out with the headset, while others investigated face cushions that were better suited for sweaty, high-intensity workouts, but was scrapped due to the battery pack and the fragile screen. A feature called "co-presence", a projection of a FaceTime user's full body was also scrapped due to unknown reasons.{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2023/06/21/vision-pro-features/|title=Vision Pro: What features were killed and what could still be coming - 9to5Mac}} === Unveiling and release === Information about a headset, then rumored to be called the Reality Pro,{{Cite web |last=Hector |first=Hamish |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Don't get excited for an Apple Reality Pro price switcheroo at WWDC |url=https://www.techradar.com/news/dont-get-excited-for-an-apple-reality-pro-price-bait-and-switch-at-wwdc |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[TechRadar]] |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606030617/https://www.techradar.com/news/dont-get-excited-for-an-apple-reality-pro-price-bait-and-switch-at-wwdc |url-status=live }} began surfacing in 2022. In May 2022, Apple executives previewed the device, including CEO [[Tim Cook]].{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=May 19, 2022 |title=Apple Shows AR/VR Headset to Board in Sign of Progress on Key Project |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-19/apple-shows-headset-to-board-in-sign-it-s-reached-advanced-stage |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221217182719/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-19/apple-shows-headset-to-board-in-sign-it-s-reached-advanced-stage |archive-date=December 17, 2022 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} The company began recruiting directors to develop content for the headset in June. One such director, [[Jon Favreau]], was enlisted to bring the dinosaurs on his [[Apple TV+]] show ''[[Prehistoric Planet]]'' to life.{{Cite web |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian |date=June 4, 2022 |title=Apple Starts Connecting the Dots for Its Next Big Thing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/04/business/apple-virtual-reality-headset.html |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The New York Times]] |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605063114/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/04/business/apple-virtual-reality-headset.html |url-status=live }} By April, Apple was attempting to attract developers to make software and services.{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=April 18, 2023 |title=Apple's AR/VR Headset to Feature Sports, Gaming, iPad Apps and Workouts |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-04-18/apple-vr-ar-headset-apps-sports-tv-fitness-gaming-wellness-ipad-features |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605205557/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-04-18/apple-vr-ar-headset-apps-sports-tv-fitness-gaming-wellness-ipad-features |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} Apple filed over 5,000 patents for technologies which contributed to the development of Vision Pro.{{Cite web |last=Cross |first=Jason |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple Vision Pro: Apple's big bet on a brand-new platform starts at $3,499 |url=https://www.macworld.com/article/1940428/apple-vision-pro-design-features-specs-price-release-date.html |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Macworld]] |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606030736/https://www.macworld.com/article/1940428/apple-vision-pro-design-features-specs-price-release-date.html |url-status=live }} The Apple Vision Pro was announced at the [[Worldwide Developers Conference#2023|Worldwide Developers Conference]] on June 5, 2023, with availability beginning in early 2024 in the United States at a starting price of {{USD|3499}} and later in 2024{{Cite web |date=2023-10-30 |title=Apple Vision Pro VR Headset Release Date Confirmed - TechShaky |url=https://techshaky.com/apple-vision-pro-vr-headset-release-date-confirmed/ |access-date=2023-11-19 |language=en-US}} in additional countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, Japan, India, Brazil, Australia, France, Germany, Spain, Italy and South Korea, at varying starting prices.{{Cite news |last=Fowler |first=Geoffrey |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple unveils Vision Pro, its $3,499 augmented-reality headset |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/06/05/apple-headset-vision-pro/ |access-date=June 5, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}} Estimates of initial shipments range from 500,000 to 1 million units.{{Cite web |last=Phelan |first=David |title=Apple Vision Pro 2024 Release Date: Mass Shipments Just Days Away, Insider Claims |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidphelan/2023/12/27/apple-vision-pro-2024-release-date-mass-shipments-just-days-away-insider-claims/ |access-date=2023-12-27 |website=Forbes |language=en}}{{Cite web |last1=McGee |first1=Patrick |last2=Bradshaw |first2=Tim |date=March 11, 2023 |title=Tim Cook bets on Apple's mixed-reality headset to secure his legacy |url=https://www.ft.com/content/86b99549-0648-4c23-ab6e-642a4ba51dff |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230513143518/https://www.ft.com/content/86b99549-0648-4c23-ab6e-642a4ba51dff |archive-date=May 13, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Financial Times]]}} On June 6, Apple acquired the AR headset startup Mira, whose technology is used at [[Super Nintendo World]]'s ''[[Mario Kart: Bowser's Challenge|Mario Kart]]'' ride. The company has a contract with the [[United States Air Force]] and [[United States Navy|Navy]]. Eleven of the company's employees were onboarded.{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/6/23751350/apple-mira-ar-headset-startup |title=Apple has bought an AR headset startup called Mira |date=June 6, 2023 |last1=Schiffer |first1=Zoe |last2=Heath |first2=Alex |work=[[The Verge]] |access-date=June 6, 2023}} ==Specifications== === Hardware === Apple Vision Pro has a [[laminated glass]] display front, an aluminum frame covered by a flexible cushion, and an adjustable headband. The frame contains five sensors, six microphones and 12 cameras. Users will see two {{Convert|1.41|in|cm|adj=on}} micro-[[OLED]] displays with a total of 23 [[megapixels]] usually running at 90 [[Frames per second|FPS]] from a maximum of 96 through the lens. The eyes are tracked by a system of LEDs and infrared cameras, which form the basis of the device's [[Iris recognition|iris scanner]] named Optic ID (used for authentication, like the iPhone's [[Face ID]]). Custom optical inserts are supported for users with prescription glasses; these lenses will attach magnetically to the main lens and are developed in partnership with [[Carl Zeiss AG]]. The device's speaker is inside the headband and is placed directly over the user's ears. It can also virtualize [[surround sound]].{{Cite web |title=Apple Vision Pro |url=https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605194140/https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro/ |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=2023-06-05 |website=Apple |language=en-US}} The Vision Pro uses the [[Apple M2]] system on a chip. It is accompanied by a co-processor known as Apple R1, which is used for real-time [[Sensor fusion|sensor input processing]]. The device can be powered by an external power supply, a {{Nowrap|[[USB-C]]}} port on a [[Mac (computer)|Mac]], or a battery pack rated for two hours of use.{{Cite web |last=Wiggers |first=Kyle |date=2023-06-05 |title=Apple Vision Pro: Here's everything you need to know |url=https://techcrunch.com/2023/06/05/apple-vision-pro-everything-you-need-to-know/ |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}}{{Cite magazine |last=Goode |first=Lauren |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple's Mixed-Reality Headset, Vision Pro, Is Here |url=https://www.wired.com/story/apple-vision-pro-specs-price-release-date/ |magazine=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |access-date=5 June 2023}}{{Cite magazine |last=Goode |first=Lauren |title=Hands on With Apple's Vision Pro: The Opposite of Disappearing |language=en-US |magazine=Wired |url=https://www.wired.com/story/apple-vision-pro-hands-on-demo/ |access-date=2023-06-10 |issn=1059-1028}} The user's face is scanned by the headset during setup to generate a ''persona''—a realistic [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]] used by OS features.{{Cite web |last=Roth |first=Emma |date=2023-06-05 |title=Apple's Vision Pro headset will turn you into a digital avatar when FaceTiming |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23750096/apple-vision-pro-headset-persona-facetime |access-date=2023-06-08 |website=The Verge |language=en-US}} During a public demo at [[Worldwide Developers Conference#2023|Worldwide Developers Conference]] (WWDC), hands-on participants faces were scanned by an iPhone with [[Face ID|TrueDepth camera]] for fitting purposes, and ears were scanned to optimize the speakers, with Apple stating this process can be done with the user's own iPhone or at an [[Apple Store]] as part of the purchase process.{{Cite web |last=Axon |first=Samuel |date=2023-06-06 |title=Hands-on with Apple Vision Pro: This is not a VR headset |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/06/hands-on-with-apple-vision-pro-this-is-not-a-vr-headset/ |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}} A "digital crown" dial on the headset is used to control the amount of virtual background occupying the user's field of view, ranging from a [[mixed-reality]] view where apps and media appear to float in the user's real-world surroundings, to completely hiding the user's surroundings. The Vision Pro has an outward-facing display called EyeSight, which displays the eyes of the user's [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] persona. Its eyes appear dimmed when in AR and obscured when in full immersion to indicate the user's environmental awareness. When someone else approaches or speaks, even if the user is fully immersed, EyeSight shows their persona's virtual eyes normally and makes the other person visible. === Software === {{Infobox OS | name = visionOS | logo = visionOS wordmark.svg | developer = Apple Inc. | family = [[Unix-like]], based on [[Darwin (operating system)|Darwin]] ([[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]]), [[iOS]], [[iPadOS]] | marketing target = [[Mixed reality]] headsets, Apple Vision Pro | supported platforms = [[ARMv8-A]] | kernel type = [[Hybrid kernel|Hybrid]] ([[XNU]]) | license = [[Proprietary software]] with open-source components | support status = Beta | working state = Current | released = Early 2024 }} Apple Vision Pro runs visionOS (internally called xrOS during its development{{Cite web |date=2023-06-09 |title=Apple visionOS was called ‘xrOS’ before last-minute change, WWDC23 keynote and developer sessions confirm it |url=https://www.theapplepost.com/2023/06/09/apple-visionos-was-called-xros-before-last-minute-change-wwdc23-keynote-and-developer-sessions-confirm-it/ |access-date=2023-10-13 |website=The Apple Post |language=en-GB}}), which is derived primarily from [[iOS]] core frameworks (including [[UIKit]], [[SwiftUI]], and [[ARKit]]), and XR-specific frameworks for [[foveated rendering]] and real-time interaction.{{Cite web |last=Wiggers |first=Kyle |date=2023-06-05 |title=visionOS is Apple's latest operating system |url=https://techcrunch.com/2023/06/05/visionos-is-apples-latest-operating-system/ |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}}{{Cite web |title=WWDC 2023 Biggest Reveals: Vision Pro Headset, iOS 17, MacBook Air and More |url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/mobile/wwdc-2023-biggest-reveals-vision-pro-headset-ios-17-macbook-air-and-more/ |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=[[CNET]] |language=en}} The operating system uses a [[3D user interaction|3D user interface]] navigated via [[finger tracking]], [[eye tracking]], and [[speech recognition]]. For example, the user can click an element by looking at it and pinching two fingers together, move the element by moving their pinched fingers, and scroll by flicking their wrist. Apps are displayed in floating [[Window (computing)|windows]] that can be arranged in 3D space. visionOS supports a virtual keyboard for text input, the [[Siri]] virtual assistant, and external [[Bluetooth]] peripherals including [[Magic Keyboard (Mac)|Magic Keyboard]], [[Magic Trackpad]], and [[gamepad]]s.{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple announces visionOS, the operating system for its Vision Pro headset |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23733874/apple-vision-pro-visionos-augmented-reality-os-specs-wwdc-2023 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605192408/https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23733874/apple-vision-pro-visionos-augmented-reality-os-specs-wwdc-2023 |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]]}} Calls can be presented via windows of participants's personas.{{Cite web |last=Axon |first=Samuel |date=2023-06-06 |title=Hands-on with Apple Vision Pro: This is not a VR headset |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/06/hands-on-with-apple-vision-pro-this-is-not-a-vr-headset/ |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}} [[The Walt Disney Company]] announced plans to develop apps for visionOS, including a [[Disney+]] app incorporating mixed-reality experiences.{{Cite web |last=Weatherbed |first=Jess |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Disney Plus is coming to Apple's Vision Pro headset |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23749382/apple-vision-pro-headset-disney-plus-tv-movies-sports-wwdc |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605194618/https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23749382/apple-vision-pro-headset-disney-plus-tv-movies-sports-wwdc |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]]}} Over 100 [[Apple Arcade]] games will be compatible with visionOS at launch.{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=2023-06-05 |title=Apple announces visionOS, the operating system for its Vision Pro headset |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23733874/apple-vision-pro-visionos-augmented-reality-os-specs-wwdc-2023 |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=The Verge |language=en-US}}{{Cite web |last=Parrish |first=Ash |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple's new VR headset will feature over 100 Apple Arcade games at launch |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23749709/apple-vision-pro-apple-arcade-wwdc-2023 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605203726/https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23749709/apple-vision-pro-apple-arcade-wwdc-2023 |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]]}} The company is working with [[Unity Technologies]] to support the [[Unity (game engine)|Unity engine]] on visionOS.{{Cite web |last=Novet |first=Jordan |date=2023-06-05 Pre-release and unveiling === Samuel Axon of ''[[Ars Technica]]'' felt that the Vision Pro was "truly something I had never seen before", noting the intuitiveness of its user interface in a choreographed demo given by Apple, and praising a dinosaur [[Technology demonstration|tech demo]] for its immersiveness. Axon felt that its displays were dim but "much better than other headsets I've used on this front, even if it still wasn’t perfect", and that the personas looked "surreal" but conveyed body language better than a more stylized avatar (such as [[Animoji]] or [[Horizon Worlds]]). He argued that the Vision Pro was not a [[virtual reality]] (VR) platform, nor a competitor to [[Meta Platforms]]' [[Reality Labs|Quest]] (formerly Oculus) product line, due to its positioning as "primarily an AR device that just happens to have a few VR features", and not as a mass market consumer product. Media outlets observed that Meta had announced the [[Meta Quest 3]] shortly before WWDC, seemingly in anticipation of Apple's announcement.{{Cite web |last=Turner |first=Nick |date=June 1, 2023 |title=Meta Announces $500 Quest 3 Headset Just Ahead of Apple Launch |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-01/meta-announces-500-quest-3-headset-just-ahead-of-apple-launch |access-date=June 1, 2023 |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]}}{{Cite web |last=Holt |first=Kris |date=June 1, 2023 |title=The Meta Quest 3 is a $499 mixed reality headset with full-color passthrough |url=https://www.engadget.com/the-meta-quest-3-is-a-499-mixed-reality-headset-with-full-color-passthrough-141204527.html |access-date=June 1, 2023 |work=[[Engadget]]}}{{Cite web |last=Lyles |first=Taylor |date=June 1, 2023 |title=Meta Officially Announces the Quest 3 |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/meta-quest-3-announced-price |access-date=June 1, 2023 |work=[[IGN]]}} Jay Peters of ''[[The Verge]]'' similarly noted that Apple had deliberately avoided presenting the Vision Pro as a VR platform, such as not referring to the device as a "headset", describing it as an AR device and "spatial computer", and only demonstrating non-VR games displayed in windows and controlled using an external gamepad, rather than fully-immersive experiences such as games and social platforms. He suggested that this positioning "leaves wiggle room for the likely future of this technology that looks nothing like a bulky VR headset: [[Smart glasses|AR glasses]]."{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=2023-06-07 |title=Apple made a VR headset, but it’ll never admit it |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/7/23750301/apple-vision-pro-headset-virtual-reality-vr-headset |access-date=2023-06-07 |website=The Verge |language=en-US}} The Vision Pro has been criticized due to its high cost, seen by some as too high to go mainstream;{{Cite web|url=https://www.creativebloq.com/news/apple-vision-pro|title=Apple Vision Pro: The good, the bad and the ugly|author1=Daniel Piper|date=June 6, 2023|website=Creative Bloq}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-vision-pro-3499-price-reveal-prompts-groans-sighs-laughter-2023-6|title=The crowd at the unveiling of Apple's Vision Pro headset let out a collective groan when they found out how wildly expensive it was|first=Pete|last=Syme|website=Business Insider}}{{Cite web |last=Plant |first=Logan |date=June 12, 2023 |title=Fans React to Apple Vision Pro Announcement With Memes, Shock Over Price Point |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/fans-react-to-apple-vision-pro-announcement-with-memes-shock-over-price-point |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230612053720/https://www.ign.com/articles/fans-react-to-apple-vision-pro-announcement-with-memes-shock-over-price-point |archive-date=June 12, 2023 |access-date=July 4, 2023 |website=IGN}} the three priciest components in the Vision Pro are its camera and sensor array, its dual Apple silicon chips, and the twin 4K micro-OLED virtual reality displays.
